availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Printer's copy, annotated and lightly corrected, of the poem first published under the title "As One by One Withdraw the Lofty Actors" in Harper's Weekly, 16 May 1885. The poem was reprinted as "Grant" in the Critic, 15 August 1885 and revised as "Death of General Grant" in the "Sands at Seventy" annex to Leaves of Grass (1888).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: As One by One Withdraw the Lofty Actors
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Literary Manuscripts in the Walt Whitman Collection, Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas at Austin
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
The verso includes a sheet of paper with the numbers "814" and "44" written upon them, which were pasted to an unfolded envelope addressed to Whitman.

lg.note:
Mr Kurtz /set this up in/ the usual way, & let me
see a proof /say by noon/ please.

head.hi: As one by one withdraw the lofty actors.

lg.l: As one by one withdraw the lofty actors
From that great play on History's stage eterne,

That lurid partial act of war and peace — of
old and new contending,

Fought out through wrath, and fears, and
dark dismays and many a long suspense,

NowAll past — and since, in countless graves re–
cedingreceding,
mellowing,

Victor's and vanquished — Lincoln's and Lee's —
now tThou with them,

Man of the mighty days — and equal to
the days!

Thou offrom the prairies! — curioustangled ‸and many-vein'd and hard has
been thy part,
To admarcation has it been enacted.

lg.l:
And still shallmayshall 2 be; — resume ‸again, thou
hero heart!

Strengthen to firmest day, O rosy
dawn of hope!

Thou dirge, I started first H to
spirit of gladness turnjoyful shout reverse— — and
thou, O grave
